Name: Physics for Scientists and Engineers, Vol. 1, 6th: Mechanics, Oscillations and Waves, Thermodynamics,

ReviewList.Text: Maybe I am stupid, but many of my friends are not getting it through this book either. Not recommand for physics beginner.
Okay book. I ordered the wrong volume. The book itself only get 3 stars because it's very difficult to learn from. If you are taking PHYS 241 at Purdue, you need volume 2, not 1!

Inside the book have no marks and one page was missing which I knew it, it was described in the original post. The corners of the book were in poor condition, folded in every direction, making the book thicker and giving it a horrible impression.
This book does not have enough example. End of chapter problems are not like examples.I think they could have some more problems related to the topics in this book.

Do Not take a class that requires this book because it is frustrating, it's solutions are incorrect half the time, and a lot of the time it doesn't even define variables or constants in the equations that it creates. And I do mean creates. HUGE waste of money and I can assure you if you're professor isn't miraculously good (which most aren't) you are not going to learn anything in the class and the textbook is not going to help at all, if any thing it will harm.

Ordered this book.  Granted I will only be using this book for a semester but I bought it thinking the condition would be "good."  I received the book fairly quickly as promised.  But the condition is bad to say the least.  It is an inconvenience to put the pages back in the book everytime I use it.  Still cheaper to buy this at $50 than new for $200
It is a book, what do you want from me? Thanks, it was a book, just as you said. Thanks

My teacher made the class use this textbook for our "Introduction to Physics with a Biological Emphasis" course. Let me tell you now, it was NOT HELPFUL. The sections that my instructor covered and focused on for two weeks probably only took a paragraph of explanation in the book and maybe a few examples. And while I understand the importance of examples for math-based courses, it would still be nice to have some background knowledge of the problem you're about to do (besides, the examples still moved too quickly in my opinion).
